metadata.title: Why Green & Silver just might be the new Black & Gold | by Peter Turner | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Why Green & Silver just might be the new Black & Gold
metadata.description: The story of Silver is a long one, and the white metal has enjoyed a rather tumultuous romance with mankind over the past millennia — though has always seemed to play second fiddle to Gold. This post…

all_paragraphs: The story of Silver is a long one, and the white metal has enjoyed a rather tumultuous romance with mankind over the past millennia — though has always seemed to play second fiddle to Gold.

This post attempts to conduct a somewhat-thorough analysis of the precious metal, whilst also serving as a bit of a ‘data science’ tutorial of sorts — as I will document many of the steps I went through whilst conducting the analysis, and provide code samples where applicable. The notebooks and some of the data can be found in this repository. For a condensed version of this post, click here.

Silver is interesting as a precious metal, in that its demand extends far beyond merely its use as jewellery and as a store of value — rather, its physical properties make it highly sought after in industry. This section will focus mainly on the current, and recent-past demand for Silver.
To get a bit of grounding, let’s look at the main points — pertaining to silver demand — that came out of The Silver Institute's 2019 World Silver Survey:
The CPM Silver Yearbook contains detailed statistics and analysis on international silver markets, the global silver fabrication demand for the past 43 years can be seen below:
(picture was taken from this blog post using data from the CPM Silver Yearbook).
It is evident that total fabrication demand has been on the rise for six consecutive years. Now, this is all good and well, but why is it increasing? To see, let's drill down into this demand:
The Silver Institute provides more granular data on (total) global supply and demand for silver, but only from 2009 up until 2018.

The data they provide is actually a JPEG image, so I had to manually record it into Excel, before reading it in again with Python. Quite a shlep, but I have added the file to the repo for this post, to save poor souls from going through similar trials in the future. The Silver closing price I scraped off a website (see the last section).

I used Pandas, Plotly, and Cufflinks to plot this data, for the above graph I actually used the online graphic design tool, Canva, to combine the silver price and demand graph (I know this can be done with Plotly too, but I couldn’t work out how to do it easily using Cufflinks). I like Plotly a lot, and I would definitely recommend it; Cufflinks is a library that helps to use Plotly easily with Pandas DataFrames.
What can be seen from the above graphs? Well — what I took from them was:
Why is the industrial demand for silver so high in comparison to other precious metals? And why is it increasing?
A lot has do do with the scientific properties of Silver as an element, Ag:

Silver has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of any metal on the face of the Earth. Not only this, but the metal is also a rather well-known biocide — meaning: it kills bacteria. (Note that resistivity is the reciprocal of conductivity).
“Silver has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of any element on the face of the Earth.”
In the next few sections of this demand analysis, we will investigate and analyze how exactly Silver is used in several main industries.

Silver’s unsurpassed conductive properties among metals mean it cannot so easily be replaced by other, less-expensive metals. Silver is also a noble metal, which means that it is resistant to corrosion and oxidation in moist air — unlike most other metals.
With these facts in mind, it may come as no surprise that electronics is, by a large margin, the number one consumer of silver in industry.

Silver is mined either directly — in silver mines — or as a by-product in Lead and Zinc mines. Smelting and refining removes the silver from the ore, after which it is usually shaped into bars or grains. Electronics demand only Silver of the highest purity — meaning no contaminants (99.9% silver). The dissolution of Silver in nitric acid produces Silver Nitrate, which can then be formed into flakes or powder — which can then, in turn, be fabricated into contacts or silver pastes. These end products are, by and large, what are used directly in electronics. Examples of where they are used are numerous, but include:

A stated previously, silver is a unique precious metal in that more than half of the supply is actually used for industrial purposes. The main driver for this is silver’s excellent reflective and conductive properties. An interesting application of silver is within the solar photovoltaic industry. Silver is used extensively in the production of solar panels.

In fact, a paste containing silver is critical is both photovoltaic cells, and 90% of crystalline silicon photovoltaic cells. The paste is used within solar cells in order to collect and transmit electrons whose movement is induced by sunlight through the photoelectric effect. In effect, silver helps conduct the electrons so as to create an electrical current; and this electricity can then be stored or consumed. The superior resistivity of silver increases the potential sunlight captured, energy conducted, and ultimately the total power that is generated in a solar cell — the efficiency of solar cells is thus somewhat proportional to their silver content.
Given the need for the global pursuit of more sustainable power sources in the face of climate change, the future of solar power and therefore solar cell production is indeed a bright one.
Two factors provide a definite threat to the unbridled increase in Silver demand due to solar: namely, thrifting and other-technology-related efficiency increases.

Thrifting is the process by which manufacturers try and cut down the amount of silver used so as to cut costs. Indeed, the amount of silver needed to produce a conductive silver paste for the PV industry may be almost halved — from 130mg per cell in 2016, to 65mg by 2028 — this is according to the report, on behalf of the Silver Institute. The amount of silver has already decreased to a much larger extent, from 400 to 130 mg from 2007 to 2016. Even with this decrease in silver content, solar cell output has actually grown and is forecasted to continue to do so; from an output wattage of 4.7 now — to 6W by 2030. This increase is due to increases in efficiency and other technological advancements in how solar panels are designed and made.

Despite all this, silver’s unmatched electroconductive qualities mean that there is, in fact, a “physical limit” on the volume of reduction in silver loadings possible in solar cell production. Simply put, there will come a point where efficiency losses outweigh the benefits achieved from using cheaper raw materials (copper, aluminium) as a substitute for silver.

Simply put, there will come a point where efficiency losses outweigh the benefits achieved from using cheaper raw materials

The report mentioned above forecasts that demand in the PV industry of about 70–80 million ounces per year with a decline to between 50–55 million in the mid-2020s. Only by 2030 is demand expected to recover, to approximately 66 million ounces per year. The World Bank’s report echoes a similar sentiment, forecasting a decline in demand due to solar PV.

What, I think, these entities fail to consider is this: do not underestimate the power of a generation brought up under the constant fear of climate change will do as a collective when they reach the age at which they are the drivers of the market.
But let us address this using a bit of analysis:
Seen below are two graphs. The first is a per year plot of the share of global energy that is renewable, the second is a per year plot of total global solar energy consumption:
It is clear that the rise of Solar energy is exponential —and the Green Revolution we are seeing will certainly not deter us from using more Solar Energy in the future.

Facebook has a really great open-source library called ‘Prophet’ — which is excellent for univariate time series forecasting. It is also extremely easy to use, let’s throw our global solar consumption data into Prophet.
The Github Gists no longer seem to embed properly into medium — so follow the link to see the code properly (or check the notebooks)The resulting forecast is shown below (download dataset here):

To get thrifting data, I used an online tool to map it in from a jpeg graph (the one shown above). I have made it available in the repository for this post. The data only range from 2009 to 2018. If we also throw this into Prophet, we get the following forecast:

Hmm. Well we know that the Silver loadings can’t drop below zero, we have also not in any way embedded our assumption that there is some ‘physical limit on the volume of reduction in silver loadings possible in solar cell production’ — and thus this is clearly not evident in our forecast.

The Silver Institute has stated in their report that they expect thrifting to continue and that in 2028 the Silver loadings used could drop to as low as 65mg per cell — lets now adjust our data (and forecast) to include this entry:

Not very helpful to be honest, but I must say: this data looks awfully like it could be fitted using an exponential function, and luckily Scipy has a very cool function that can do this for us in a Jiffy — using least squares regression.
Before we do this, though, let normalize our Silver loadings dataset— from 0 to 1. We can do this using Sklearn’s MinMaxScaler.
Our normalized data looks like this:
Now we can use Scipy’s curve_fit function to fit the following function (an exponential curve) to the data.

Notice that I limited the bounds for c so as to get a curve that at least tended towards a value that was less than 65mg per cell (estimated loadings in 2028 by the Silver Institute). The result is as follows:
In the above graph, 2.00 on the x-axis corresponds to the year 2047. The Silver loadings tend to a value of around 0.045 — or 45mg/cell. So this is our “physical limit”.
Now — of course, this curve is a bit of a thumb suck, I tweaked the bounds so that it essentially lowered the graph to a value that ‘looked about right’, even somewhat conservative.
Now, where this gets really interesting, is when you combine the two:

I will not post the code for the above graph here, simply because it took a lot of tweaking, scaling, creating new DataFrames and whatnot (my Pandas skills may leave something to be desired too). A separate notebook containing all the code is, however, available here. Please, guys, check my logic on all of this and get back to me in the comments — I could easily have screwed something up and would like to know about it if that is the case.

This entire exercise is of course assuming sole and direct proportionality of solar Silver demand to both solar consumption, and silver loadings per solar cell — which does seem to make sense: of course solar Silver demand is proportional to ‘amount of silver in each cell’ as well as ‘amount of solar panel energy consumed’ — right?

Anyway. What it looks like, if that graph is to be trusted, is that we are at a turning point for the solar Silver demand. If there is indeed a physical limit to the amount of silver that will continue to be used in solar panels, then it seems that — assuming an increase of solar consumption equal or similar to our forecast — the demand for silver from the solar industry will begin to climb relatively rapidly in the future, particularly when it reaches this limit.
What it looks like, is that we are at a turning point for the solar Silver demand.
The above graph also seems to correspond with the past CPM Silver Yearbook data (as seen on GoldSilver’s blog post):
A biocide is defined in the European legislation as a “chemical substance or microorganism intended to destroy, deter, render harmless, or exert a controlling effect on any harmful organism”.

Silver is a well know, and broad-spectrum biocide, proving to be effective in quashing a growing list of bacterial threats, including legionnaire’s disease, E. Coli, Streptococcus, and MSRA; these microbes account for a large proportion of germs that we encounter on a daily basis. Because of these properties, silver has for a long time been used in water treatment, being sold in many filters worldwide.

Although the WHO World Health Organisation has declared that — in its current applications — that Silver is “not an effective disinfectant for drinking water”, developments in the field nanotechnology and the use of Silver Nanoparticles may see this change in upcoming years. Recent studies have shown that silver loss from Ag (Silver) Nanoparticle sheets were lower than the standards for drinking water put forward by both WHO and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), with the conclusion that filtration through paper deposited with Ag Nanoparticles could be an effective emergency water treatment. In addition to this, recent studies have been done investigating the plausibility of using Silver as a biocide for spacecraft water systems. In fact, NASA is considering silver as the future biocide for exploration.

Recent studies have shown that silver loss from Ag (Silver) Nanoparticle sheets were lower than the standards for drinking water put forward by both WHO and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), with the conclusion that filtration through paper deposited with Ag Nanoparticles could be an effective emergency water treatment.

On the use of Silver in the treatment of water, to summarise; if you, like Michael Burry (the man behind the story of ‘The Big Short’), believe that the future will bring a considerable shortage of accessible freshwater — and that this same future will see a drastic increase in space exploration, you may just want to hedge your bets on this fascinating metal.
An analysis of the Silver supply is now due, and the supply data is certainly interesting too.
The total global Silver supply is shown on the graph below:
Again, the Silver Institute’s data is more granular:

The decrease in the supply of Silver from mines seems to be due to the Silver price. I used the Python libraries requests and BeautifulSoup to scrape the historical Silver prices, before plotting with Plotly:

The low silver price means that Silver mines have been struggling to operate at a profit — leading to them committing less-and-less capital into exploratory projects and into increasing production. Note in the graph below how every single country in the list of top 10 Silver producers, is mining less silver.

Also, even if the Silver price spikes, it will take some time, years even, for Silver mines to increase the output — this ‘lag’ could mean an extension of the period in which high Silver demand is met with an inadequate supply.
“…even if the Silver price spikes, it will take some time, years even, for Silver mines to increase the output”

According to GoldSilver’s blog post earlier this year, the silver “mine capacity” — the amount of Silver expected to enter the market from new mines — has dropped extremely sharply (“fallen off a cliff”, to quote); it has fallen almost 90% since 2013, and is also a result of the low Silver price (low price means people are less likely to start new Silver mines).

Also, according to the CPM yearbook, the Silver scrap is also down (a 20-year low) — again, low Silver prices seem to be the culprit as scrap dealers are finding it increasingly difficult to make money.

Now if the global Silver demand increases, but the supply remains stagnant — where will the Silver come from? To quote, again, from GoldSilver’s post: “Not from government stockpiles. Governments don’t stockpile silver anymore. No nation uses it in their currency, so they stopped hoarding it”.

Whilst the previous sections have looked at Silver through the lens of Supply-Demand Theory with a specific focal point on the industrial applications of Silver, this section will take a more macroeconomic approach — and will explore several ideas and potential events that could dramatically influence the price of Silver in the future.

According to billionaire investor and hedge fund manager Ray Dalio, the economy works in a simple — and mechanical — way. He explains this concept in a fantastic YouTube video, but essentially he says that the economy is driven by three main forces:

According to Dalio, ‘debt-swings’ occur in two big cycles (long-term, and short-term) of 75–100 years, and 5–8 years respectively; and at this point in time (December 2019) we are in a period similar to that in 1935–1940, which exhibited the following, shared traits:

In Dalio’s words: “the next downturn will happen, probably in a couple of years” and it will be one in which the social and political problems will be great — this added to the decrease in effectiveness of the ‘levers’ used by central banks (interest rates, quantitative easing) will mean that we will struggle to ‘reverse’ the next downturn. It will be a hard one.
“The next downturn will happen probably in the next couple of years” — Ray Dalio, September 2019

In addition to this, people such as Michael Burry (the man who successfully predicted the 2008 housing market bubble) have recently been talking about how we may currently be in an index bubble. Burry has made the point that “Passive investments are inflating stock and bond prices in a similar way that collateralized debt obligations did for subprime mortgages more than 10 years ago…like most bubbles, the longer it goes on, the worse the crash will be”.

“Passive investments are inflating stock and bond prices in a similar way that collateralized debt obligations did for subprime mortgages more than 10 years ago, Burry told Bloomberg News.” — Michael Burry, September 2019

Now I don’t know whether we are, indeed, in a bubble or not. Nor how far away the next downturn/recession is. But I do assume that we haven’t had our last one; and what happens during an economic downturn? The answer is that investors flock to precious metals — like Silver — and this would mean a gargantuan increase in the Silver demand.

The countries China and India deserve special mention in this post. These two countries, in particular, seem to be the ones to watch when it comes to Silver (demand & supply). The demand for Silver fabrication in China has grown over 420% in the past 18 years — this with an inflation rate lower than that of the USA. China was also the main contributor to the Silver demand in 2018, accounting for almost half of the new solar panel installations as well as reporting a 2% increase in silver production in relation to 2017, realizing 114.9 Moz; Silvercorp’s Ying Mining District enjoyed the highest improvements (both in throughput and in grade).
Looking at the above charts, it would seem that China is set to benefit from a large chunk of the electronics and renewable energy powered Silver demand increase (assuming it does increase).
It may indeed be a good idea to invest in the Chinese Silver supply-end (mines and scrap companies) — as this is where China will look to meet their demand most cheaply.

India, on the other hand, seems to be more interested in Silver as a store of value. Looking at the above treemaps, India was the top importer of Silver in 2017. Looking at the world as a whole, after being in decline for two consecutive years, the total global physical silver buying rose 5 percent to 161.0 Moz in 2018 — and much of this spike in demand was attributable to India. India saw an increase of physical Silver purchase of 53 percent, also dominating the Silver bullion trade, with imports increasing to 36 percent (the highest level since 2015).
India’s silver jewellery fabrication has increased by 16% year-on-year to 76.5 Moz (2,378 t) in 2018. India may indeed be a significant global Silver demand driver in the upcoming years.

This is the section where I’ve decided to sort of stuff everything else — that which didn’t seem to fit elsewhere. We will have a look at possible future applications of Silver, as well as a bit of technical analysis (Gold/Silver ratio).

Due to its excellent electric conductivity, Silver is widely used in and around the electric powertrain and other applications that are increasingly featured in hybrid Internal Combustion Engine (ICE) cars and Electric Vehicles (EVs) alike. Also — regarding water treatment — nanotechnology may create an environment in which Silver could be very effective in emergency water treatment, this is why NASA has it shortlisted as the future biocide for space exploration.

The gold-silver ratio represents the amount of silver necessary to purchase one the equivalent amount of gold. What is interesting is that the ratio is nearing record-high levels, which suggests that Silver is becoming increasingly undervalued relative to Gold.
The above graph was plotted using the code below, which essentially uses Plotly and Cufflinks to plot the ratio of the Gold & Silver prices (scraped from the internet).

And that’s all, folks! Thanks for reading, and props to you if you made it this far— I enjoyed doing this one and hope some of you found some value in it. Please don’t take the piece as hard financial/investment advice — I am not an experienced investor, and Silver could even be a terrible investment. I am very interested to see what really happens with the metal in the future.
